thread.title: JMU's Lee trending in right direction after long journey
thread.title_full: JMU's Lee trending in right direction after long journey

title: JMU's Lee trending in right direction after long journey
text:
JMU's Lee trending in right direction after long journey 
Posted 6:43 p.m. yesterday Your friends e-mail addresses (comma separated): * Subject: * Are you human? * You must enter the characters with black color that stand out from the other characters 
Harrisonburg, Va. â€” Quarterback Vad Lee Led Hillside High School to the 2010 North Carolina State Championship. 
"Obviously winning the state championship at Hillside was special so I keep that with me everywhere I go," Lee said. 
Lee first enrolled at Georgia Tech where in two years he produced over 2,000 yards passing and over 1,000 yards rushing with 32 touchdowns. But the fit wasn't right and Lee decided to transfer to James Madison. The Dukes' head coach is Everett Withers, the former North Carolina coach who had tried to convince Lee to become a Tar Heel. 
"He does a lot of good things leadership wise to help this football team," Withers said. "He's a really good football player who has a lot of those intangibles that you like in a leader." 
And he has the right talent you look for in a quarterback. In an upset at SMU, Lee had 565 yards of total offense. This past Saturday, a modest 264 yards of total offense in the win at Elon. 
But the game was just as special as SMU because Lee got to play in front of so many friends and family. 
"It's a special feeling coming back home and playing," Lee said. "Every time I come home, I seem to have success." 
Lee has never lost a college game he has played in his home state of North Carolina. He's a perfect 4-0 with over 1,000 yards of total offense and 14 touchdowns. No matter where Lee goes, the spotlight follows. 
"It's something I didn't expect, but nothing really catches me off guard any more because I've been up and I've been down," Lee said. 
The arrow is currently pointing up from an individual and team standpoint. James Madison is 7-0 and ranked 4th in the nation at the FCS level. They will also be the backdrop for this week's ESPN College Gameday. 
"We focus on us mostly," Lee said. "We feel like if we take care of us and do our job description then we'll be fine." Credits
